item.title: acetaldehyde
item.description: Musty, moldy Present in pretty much all wines.

item.title: diacetyl
item.description: Oak, butter, butterscotch, roasted nuts. Common in Chardonnay and Pinot Noir.

item.title: Grape Varieties
item.description: Wine is usually made with grapes, but they’re not like the ones you find in the grocery store. All wine grapes comes from a single species (vitis vinifera) and - compared to other grapes - they are smaller, sweeter, have thicker skins and contain seeds. There are over 1,300 wine grape varieties used in commercial production, the top 100 of these varieties making up 75% of the world’s vineyards. Cabernet Sauvignon is the most planted variety, but other popular examples are Merlot, Tempranillo, Air√©n, Chardonnay, Syrah, Grenache Noir, Sauvignon Blanc and Pinot Noir.

item.title: isoamyl acetate
item.description: Vinegar, bananas. Common in commercial wines fermented in low temperatures to be more fruity.

item.title: Methoxipyrazines
item.description: Herbaceous, green notes, grass, bell pepper, green pepper. Common in Sauvignon Blanc and Cabernet Sauvignon, specially in less-ripe harvests.

item.title: vanillin

item.title: Vintage
item.description: Wine grapes take an entire season to ripen, and thus, wine is produced just once a year. Hence, the output of a vineyard can be identified by its year. When you see a vintage year listed on the label, that‚Äôs the year the grapes were picked and made into wine.
